# Hunt Research Citations

This document is used to record and organize the citations for the research conducted during the hunt. Properly documenting sources ensures transparency, verifiability, and reliability of the research.

## Citation Format

Each citation should include the following details:

- **Author(s)**: The individual(s) or organization that produced the resource. If an individual author is not clearly identified, use the producing organization.
- **Title**: The title of the article, research paper, or resource.
- **Source**: Where the resource was published (e.g., journal, website, vendor documentation).
- **Date**: The publication date or last update.
- **URL**: The link to the resource (if applicable).

Each citation must support at least one specific claim made in the research report.

## Example Citation Format

- **Author(s)**: Smith, J., & Doe, A.
- **Title**: "Understanding Kerberos Authentication and Its Abuse in Windows Environments."
- **Source**: Security Journal, Vol. 12, Issue 3.
- **Date**: March 2023.
- **URL**: https://example.com/kerberos-authentication-abuse

## Citation Sections

### System Internals Sources

List all sources used to gather information about the normal behavior of the system being researched. This may include official documentation, engineering resources, and technical specifications.

**Example:**

- **Author(s)**: Microsoft
- **Title**: "Kerberos Authentication Protocol Overview"
- **Source**: Microsoft Documentation
- **Date**: 2024
- **URL**: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/identity-protection/kerberos

### Adversary Tradecraft Sources

Record all sources that provide insights into how adversaries exploit system internals. This includes threat intelligence reports, security blogs, and research papers.

**Example:**

- **Author(s)**: The MITRE Corporation
- **Title**: "Kerberos Ticket-Granting Service Abuse (Kerberoasting)"
- **Source**: MITRE ATT&CK Framework
- **Date**: January 2024
- **URL**: https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1203/
